body:
Yes that would be a great addition! 

In terms of design, the main issue is how to integrate this into the pipeline. The workflow for featurizers is slightly different compared to standard series-to-series transformers. During prediction, you first need to generate features before calling the predict method of the forecaster. 

We've had some previous discussions on this (see e.g. these [notes](https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/blob/main/steps/01_forecasting_api/forecasting_pipeline.md)). 

My preference would be to define a new class for featurizers which closely follows the forecaster API with `fit` and `predict` and extend the pipeline class to handle that.
but why can it not be a transformer? As the calendar information has to be passed as `X`, the `ForecastingPipeline` would anyway transform `X`, so it would just add the columns?

Yes, exactly, why not?

If it's a transformer applied to `X` (not `y`), in predict it would be applied to `X` *before* predict is called, and the transformed `X` (with calendar indicator) would be fed to predict. So it seems all is fine?
My thinking was that you may also want to generate these features if you only have a target series and no exogenous data. That wouldn't be covered by the transformer.

@mloning for this case there would be some solutions:

1. Using `ForecastingPipeline`, so the `CalendarTransformer` would also add columns if `Z is None`. So given a univariate data where user wants to add calendar data as `X`, then the user must use a `ForecastingPipeline` and we would have to accept `Z is None`. If user wants to also transform `y` then nested with with a `TransformedTargetForecaster`.

2. Other solution would be this:
```python
forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(...)
forecaster.fit(y, X=CalendarTransformer().fit_transform(None))
```
So we would have to accept `Z is None`. 

3. Otherwise the user would have to give a dummy `DataFrame` like this:
```python
forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(...)
forecaster.fit(y, X=CalendarTransformer().fit_transform(pd.DataFrame(index=y.index)))
```

Yes, the `X=None` is an unfortunate edge case here.

I would actually treat it as follows:
* change to base class: if `X` is None in `fit`, the input to `X` in `_fit` is an empty `pd.DataFrame` with the same index as `y`.
* may require some dependent changes that checks for `X` is `None` in `_fit`.
* `CalendarTransformer` only looks at the index and adds the features there.
* pipeline applied to this `X` should then work out of the box, no edge case treatment necessary

Still seems like a tricky problem.

Passing an empty `pd.DataFrame` seems unintuitive to me. In a way, empty data is also an indicator of an error so we may want to check for that at some point in the future. 

Allowing `None` in the transformer interface would be a major interface change. 

> change to base class: if X is None in fit, the input to X in _fit is an empty pd.DataFrame with the same index as y.

When we do this change, would we not have to update all forecasters that use `X` to now ignore an empty `X`? Making all forecaster having to deal with an empty `X` internally doesn't seem right to me. `None` is the expected value here for an optional input argument (for users and developers).   

To me, this seems like a perfect use case for making some progress on the more advanced pipelining, but that would involve some extra design work I think.

or, we could simply decide that it's not worth letting this edge case stall development and lead to major design discussions, and simply add the caveat that calendar feature adder only works if you have a non-empty `X` and be done with it'?

Yes, that's also what I would prefer if no-one has the capacity to work on the pipeline, so happy to add the holiday featurizer now and think about the pipeline later. 

The simplest pipeline solution I can think of would be add a new estimator type (i.e. a featurizer) and to make distinction inside the pipeline based on estimator types.

I think also its a good idea to just ignore this edge case for now. And there is still a workaround for advanced users with the solution I mentioned:

> forecaster.fit(y, X=CalendarTransformer().fit_transform(pd.DataFrame(index=y.index)))

issue.title: [ENH] Add holiday transformer

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
While there is a `DateTimeFeatures` transformer to get date/time features from a time series (see https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1273), we don't have a transformer for handling holidays. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A `HolidaysFeatures` transformer that creates dummies for holidays based on a date-time index.
